From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

**Gwendolyne Maxine** "**Gwen** " **Stacy**[1][2] is a
[fictional](/wiki/Fictional "Fictional") character who appears in American
[comic books](/wiki/Comic_book "Comic book") published by [Marvel
Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics"), usually as a [supporting
character](/wiki/Supporting_character "Supporting character") in those
featuring [Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man"). A college student, she
was a long-term romantic interest for [Peter Parker](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-
Man") before she was murdered by the [Green Goblin](/wiki/Green_Goblin "Green
Goblin") ([Norman Osborn](/wiki/Norman_Osborn "Norman Osborn")). Spider-Man
writers and fans often debate whether Peter's "one true love" is Gwen Stacy or
[Mary Jane Watson](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson") (Peter's later
girlfriend and wife). Stories published long after her death indicate that
Gwen still holds a special place in his heart.

The character has been portrayed by [Bryce Dallas
Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas Howard") in the 2007 film
_[Spider-Man 3](/wiki/Spider-Man_3 "Spider-Man 3")_ and by [Emma
Stone](/wiki/Emma_Stone "Emma Stone") in the 2012
[reboot](/wiki/Reboot_\(fiction\) "Reboot \(fiction\)") film _[The Amazing
Spider-Man](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_\(2012_film\) "The Amazing Spider-Man
\(2012 film\)")_ and its sequel _[The Amazing Spider-Man
2](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_2 "The Amazing Spider-Man 2")_. In the
upcoming 2018 film _[Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse](/wiki/Spider-
Man:_Into_the_Spider-Verse "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse")_ , the
character will be voiced by [Hailee Steinfeld](/wiki/Hailee_Steinfeld "Hailee
Steinfeld").

Created by writer [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") and artist [Steve
Ditko](/wiki/Steve_Ditko "Steve Ditko"), Gwen Stacy first appeared in _[The
Amazing Spider-Man](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man "The Amazing Spider-Man")_
#31 (December 1965).[3]

## Fictional character
biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Fictional character biography")]

### Early history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early history")]

In her initial appearances, Peter Parker met Gwen while both were studying as
undergraduates at [Empire State University](/wiki/Empire_State_University
"Empire State University"),[4] but with [Aunt May](/wiki/Aunt_May "Aunt May")
in the hospital, Peter was troubled and ignored her advances. She dated both
[Flash Thompson](/wiki/Flash_Thompson "Flash Thompson") and [Harry
Osborn](/wiki/Harry_Osborn "Harry Osborn") to make Peter jealous. Gradually,
however, a romance developed; Gwen, a science major, appreciated Peter's
intellect. Their relationship began almost immediately after Peter stopped
going out with [Mary Jane Watson](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson"),
whom he began to see as shallow and self-absorbed.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Later issues introduced Gwen's father, NYPD Captain [George
Stacy](/wiki/George_Stacy "George Stacy"). Though her father was both fond of
Peter and supportive of his alter-ego Spider-Man, he ultimately strained
Peter's relationship with Gwen after being killed by falling debris during a
battle involving Spider-Man and [Doctor Octopus](/wiki/Doctor_Octopus "Doctor
Octopus").[5][6] Gwen blamed Spider-Man for his death, and left for Europe to
cope with her loss. She wanted Peter to ask her to marry him and convince her
to stay, but his guilt stopped him from proposing.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] Gwen's
feelings for Peter eventually prompted her to return to New York, and their
relationship was rekindled.[7]

According to Lee, who scripted all of the stories featuring Gwen Stacy up to
this point, the original intent was for Gwen Stacy to be Spider-Man's central
love interest, "but no matter how we [i.e. Lee and his artist/co-plotter
collaborators] wrote it, Mary Jane always seemed more interesting!"[8][9]

### Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Death")]

Main article: [The Night Gwen Stacy Died](/wiki/The_Night_Gwen_Stacy_Died "The
Night Gwen Stacy Died")

[Gerry Conway](/wiki/Gerry_Conway "Gerry Conway") and [Roy
Thomas](/wiki/Roy_Thomas "Roy Thomas") succeeded Stan Lee as writer and
editor, respectively, of _The Amazing Spider-Man_. Together with inker [John
Romita, Sr.](/wiki/John_Romita,_Sr. "John Romita, Sr."), they came to the
decision to have Gwen Stacy killed off.[10] It was Romita who first suggested
the idea, during a plotting session with Conway when Romita was still
penciller on _The Amazing Spider-Man_.[11] Conway later said his contribution
to the decision was motivated by a desire to bring Mary Jane Watson to the
forefront,[11][12] as he shared Lee's feeling that she was a more interesting
character than Gwen Stacy: "[Mary Jane] hadn't lost the edge that made her an
interesting character. Gwen didn't have an edge. She was just a nice
person."[13]

The [Green Goblin](/wiki/Green_Goblin "Green Goblin") kidnaps Gwen Stacy and
throws her off the [George Washington Bridge](/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge
"George Washington Bridge") in [_The Amazing Spider-Man_
#121](/wiki/The_Night_Gwen_Stacy_Died "The Night Gwen Stacy Died") (June
1973). Both the decision to kill Gwen and the method in which Marvel
implemented it remain controversial among fans because some believe that Peter
himself was the one who caused her death. The death became a pivotal point in
both Spider-Man’s history and in [American comic
books](/wiki/American_comic_book "American comic book") in general. Many point
to Gwen's death as the end of the [Silver Age of
Comics](/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Comics "Silver Age of Comics").[14] Before her
death, except possibly as part of an origin story, superheroes did not fail so
catastrophically, nor did the hero's loved ones die so suddenly and without
warning.[15][16][17]

In his book _[The Physics of Superheroes](/wiki/The_Physics_of_Superheroes
"The Physics of Superheroes")_ , physicist [James
Kakalios](/wiki/James_Kakalios "James Kakalios") writes that, consistent with
[Newton's laws of motion](/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion "Newton's laws of
motion"), the sudden stop would have killed Gwen Stacy.[18] The comic book
_Civil War: Casualties of War: Captain America/Iron Man_ (2007) concurred that
the proximate cause of death was the sudden stop during a high-speed fall. An
issue of _Peter Parker/Spider-Man_ revisits the issue, and further confirms
Gwen died of a broken neck due to the use of the webbing.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] On the
other hand, in the 1987 edition of the _[Official Handbook of the Marvel
Universe](/wiki/Official_Handbook_of_the_Marvel_Universe "Official Handbook of
the Marvel Universe")_ , Gwen’s death is attributed to the fall, not to
Spider-Man’s webbing.

Within the [Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics"), Gwen Stacy's
death has enormous repercussions. [Mary Jane Watson](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson
"Mary Jane Watson") feels the loss of Gwen deeply and becomes a more mature,
compassionate person. Gwen's death also draws Peter and Mary Jane into a
closer friendship, and eventually to romance.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] Miles
Warren, one of Gwen's professors, was secretly in love with her. Following her
death, Warren goes insane and adopts the persona of the
[Jackal](/wiki/Jackal_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Jackal \(Marvel Comics\)").[19] In
the fourth and final issue of the miniseries _[Marvels](/wiki/Marvels
"Marvels")_ (April 1994), photographer Phil Sheldon befriends Gwen Stacy, who
has absolved Spider-Man of any blame for her father's death. Gwen's simple
faith in heroes convinces Sheldon of the purpose of the "Marvels" (i.e.,
superheroes)—to protect innocents such as Gwen. He resolves to write a book to
praise the heroes and what they should mean to humanity. When the Green Goblin
kidnaps Gwen and holds her hostage to bait Spider-Man, Sheldon frantically
follows the resulting chase in a taxi and witnesses her death. While it is
reported that she died from the shock of the fall, Sheldon thinks it looks
like something else. Sheldon's faith in the Marvels is shattered.[20]

### Clones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Clones")]

Following the publication of _The Amazing Spider-Man_ #121, Stan Lee (who had
since become Marvel's publisher) was frequently criticized by fans during his
public appearances for killing off Gwen Stacy.[12] Lee, who had also found the
character's death objectionable,[10] insisted that Conway write a story
bringing her back.[12] Conway strongly objected since he felt any sort of
resurrection would break the plausibility of the stories, but ultimately gave
in under the condition that after reviving Gwen, he could write her out of the
book as soon as he wanted.[13] He decided that cloning would be the best means
to bring the character back.

In the resulting story, set approximately two years after Gwen Stacy's
death,[21] "Gwen" reappears, perfectly healthy but with no memory of the time
since her death. This story, published in _Amazing Spider-Man_ #144 (May
1975), initiated the [original Clone
Saga](/wiki/Clone_Saga#The_original_Clone_Saga "Clone Saga"). At the end of
that story, Gwen's clone, a creation of Spider-Man villain the
[Jackal](/wiki/Jackal_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Jackal \(Marvel Comics\)"), leaves to
find a new life for herself, coming to accept that she is not really the same
person who had a relationship with Peter Parker.[22]

In the 1988 crossover "[The Evolutionary War](/wiki/The_Evolutionary_War "The
Evolutionary War")", the [High Evolutionary](/wiki/High_Evolutionary "High
Evolutionary"), who had once been Miles Warren's teacher, captures Gwen's
clone. He is dismayed to learn that Miles Warren has perfected the art of
cloning and thus lies to the New Men that it was nothing more than a genetic
construct created by a virus that he injected into his apprentice, Joyce
Delaney.[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

During the second "[Clone Saga](/wiki/Clone_Saga "Clone Saga")", Gwen Stacy's
clone, now married to a clone of Professor Warren named Warren Miles, sees a
copy of Peter Parker's book of Spider-Man photos, _Webs_ , and remembers (to
an extent) her real history. She returns to New York City. During this
storyline, she again disappears from Spider-Man's life. It was revealed the
Gwen Stacy clone introduced in _Amazing Spider-Man_ #144 was in fact the
second Gwen clone Miles Warren created and has been living in London under the
name Joyce Delaney. This clone is murdered by the Gwen Stacy clone known as
Abby-L.[23]

Another Gwen clone appears in _The Amazing Spider-Man_ #399 (March 1995). This
clone believes she is the real Gwen.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] She dies
from clone degeneration in _Spider-Man_ #56 (March 1995), the next issue of
the story arc.[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

A further Gwen clone appears in the "Sibling Rivalry" crossover storyline
between _[Superior Spider-Man Team-Up](/wiki/Superior_Spider-Man_Team-Up
"Superior Spider-Man Team-Up")_ and _[Scarlet Spider](/wiki/Scarlet_Spider
"Scarlet Spider")_. She joins the Jackal (alongside
[Carrion](/wiki/Carrion_\(comics\) "Carrion \(comics\)") and a regular Miles
Warren clone) in capturing [Superior Spider-Man](/wiki/Superior_Spider-Man
"Superior Spider-Man") and [Kaine](/wiki/Kaine_Parker "Kaine Parker").[24] She
is sympathetic towards "Peter" and Kaine, but at the same time utterly loyal
to the Jackal. When the Spiders break free, Superior Spider-Man disarms and
attempts to kill her, but is stopped by Kaine. When the Jackal's lab is
engulfed in flames, Kaine offers to save her, but she refuses, and is
seemingly consumed by the fire.[25]

### "Sins Past"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: "Sins Past"")]

The story arc "Sins Past" by [J. Michael
Straczynski](/wiki/J._Michael_Straczynski "J. Michael Straczynski") in _The
Amazing Spider-Man_ #509–514 (August 2004–January 2005) reveals [Norman
Osborn](/wiki/Norman_Osborn "Norman Osborn"), the Green Goblin's alter ego,
fathered twins, a boy and a girl, with Gwen Stacy, to whom she gave birth
while in [France](/wiki/France "France") shortly before her death. She vowed
she would raise them with Peter (despite the fact that he was not aware of
Gwen's infidelity) and refused to allow Norman access to them. Seeing her as a
threat to his potential heirs, the Green Goblin killed Gwen. Norman Osborn
then raised Gwen's two children, a boy and a girl named [Gabriel and
Sarah](/wiki/Gabriel_Stacy_and_Sarah_Stacy "Gabriel Stacy and Sarah
Stacy").[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Straczynski later stated he originally wanted to make Peter Parker the father
of Gwen's kids but the editors vetoed the idea. They felt it would age Peter
Parker too much if he had two adult children. The whole creative and editorial
team then decided Norman Osborn would be the father.[26] In an e-mail to the
comic book website [Newsarama](/wiki/Newsarama "Newsarama"), Straczynski
claimed he regretted the version of "Sins Past" that went to press, and he had
hoped to "[retcon](/wiki/Retcon "Retcon")" it out of continuity during the
events of the then-recent "[One More Day](/wiki/Spider-Man:_One_More_Day
"Spider-Man: One More Day")" storyline: "I wanted to retcon the Gwen twins out
of continuity, which was something I always assumed I could do at the end of
my run. I wasn't allowed to do this, and yes, it pissed me off."[27] In the
original plans for "One More Day", the story would have ended with Gwen Stacy
being resurrected by Mephisto's reality-warping spell along with Harry Osborn,
but it was eventually decided to let her remain dead. Her son, Gabriel, has
reappeared in subsequent stories.

### Dead No More: The Clone
Conspiracy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Dead No More: The Clone Conspiracy")]

In the _[Clone Conspiracy](/wiki/Dead_No_More:_The_Clone_Conspiracy "Dead No
More: The Clone Conspiracy")_ storyline, a flashback revealed that Gwen Stacy
was conscious during Spider-Man and Green Goblin's battle on the bridge, and
as she was falling to her death. She overheard their conversation and
discovered Peter is Spider-Man. She was angry at Peter for keeping this secret
and for his involvement in her father's death.[28]

In the present, Gwen is supposedly revived by the [Jackal](/wiki/Ben_Reilly
"Ben Reilly") with his clones. The Jackal claims that this one is not a clone
but the real Gwen who was harvested from her remains and still has all her
memories, including those of her death. The Jackal offers Gwen the opportunity
to be his business partner as he tries to change the world with his new
technology. Gwen is hesitant about this new life at first but accepts it when
the Jackal shows that he has reanimated the clone of her father, who is much
better than he was before he died.[28] When Spider-Man arrives at the
incorporation and discovers the Jackal's experiments, he is surprised by
Gwen's presence and notes that unlike the other people the Jackal revived, who
were all clones, Gwen does not trigger his spider-sense, making him wonder if
she was the real one. He is attacked by the "reborn" [Doctor
Octopus](/wiki/Doctor_Octopus "Doctor Octopus") before he can question the
issue further.[28]

After the Jackal breaks up the fight and shows Spider-Man around the New U,
George Stacy clone recognizes something off about Gwen's face and points his
gun at her. It was revealed that the Gwen clone was actually her Earth-65
counterpart [Spider-Woman](/wiki/Spider-Woman_\(Gwen_Stacy\) "Spider-Woman
\(Gwen Stacy\)") who assists Spider-Man in escaping. The real Gwen is
kidnapped by [Kaine](/wiki/Kaine_Parker "Kaine Parker") and taken to [Parker
Industries](/wiki/Parker_Industries "Parker Industries") to be studied. Kaine
reveals that he and Spider-Woman came to this Earth to assist Spider-Man
because they saw that Spider-Man allying with the Jackal's offer on other
worlds results in a global disaster.[29] Rhino and Electro are sent to
retrieve Gwen after attacking the staff, but Gwen tells them to take Kaine
with him too because the condition could help with Jackal's experiments. Anna
Maria Marconi also volunteers to come with because she has studied both Kaine
and the drug.[30]

When Spider-Man is taken to Haven, he catches up with Gwen in the household in
the facility, where she tries to convince him to support New U Technologies.
Peter still has a hard time believing she is the real Gwen given his other
experiences with clones. Gwen tries justifying her existence by telling Peter
her memories, including how she overheard the Green Goblin talking to Spider-
Man before her death. Peter thinks she died hating him, but Gwen said that she
did not hate him, but rather died feeling betrayed. Peter again still has
doubts towards Gwen not being a clone. She tries kissing him, to no avail
which only pushes him to put the mask back on. Gwen witnesses Jackal order the
villains clone to kill Spider-Man and wants to help.[31]

Doctor Octopus pulls a switch that activates the Carrion Virus in all of the
revived, including Gwen and George, and causes them to start rapidly
decaying.[32] After Gwen's father deteriorates in her arms, she assists
Spider-Man by helping him get to the lab. When the villains clone get to the
lab doors, Gwen locks Spider-Man inside the lab and sacrifices herself towards
the villains to give him more time. Following the Carrion Virus being
thwarted, Spider-Man and Anna check the building and see that Gwen has been
reduced to dust.[33]

## Other versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other versions")]

### "Age of
Apocalypse"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: "Age of Apocalypse"")]

In the two-issue mini-series _X-Universe_ , which details what happened to the
rest of the Marvel Universe during the "[Age of
Apocalypse](/wiki/Age_of_Apocalypse "Age of Apocalypse")" storyline, the Green
Goblin never killed Gwen Stacy. Instead she became the bodyguard of Donald
Blake, who, in this reality, had never become [the Mighty
Thor](/wiki/Thor_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Thor \(Marvel Comics\)"). Sometime later
in the mainstream universe in X-Man #37, the Age of Apocalypse version of Gwen
is pulled from her reality to the mainstream Earth's George Washington Bridge,
much to Spider-Man's shock.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### Gwenpool[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Gwenpool")]

Main article: [Gwenpool](/wiki/Gwenpool "Gwenpool")

Due to the popularity of [Spider-Gwen](/wiki/Spider-Gwen "Spider-Gwen"), in
June 2015 Marvel published variant covers for 20 of their current series,
which saw Gwen Stacy re-imagined as other Marvel characters, such as [Doctor
Strange](/wiki/Doctor_Strange "Doctor Strange"), [Groot](/wiki/Groot "Groot")
and [Wolverine](/wiki/Wolverine_\(character\) "Wolverine \(character\)").[34]
One of those variants, for "Deadpool's Secret Secret Wars #2", featured an
amalgam of Gwen Stacy and [Deadpool](/wiki/Deadpool "Deadpool") dubbed
"Gwenpool", which turned out to be especially popular with the fans.[35] As
the result, Marvel produced two stories featuring Gwenpool as a character, a
backup story in the series "[Howard the Duck](/wiki/Howard_the_Duck "Howard
the Duck")", and a one-shot "Gwenpool Holiday Special #1".[36] A retcon in the
Howard the Duck #1 backup it was revealed her name is actually "Gwen Poole",
not Gwen Stacy, or even an alternate version of Gwen Stacy. Following the
publication of the one-shot, an ongoing series titled _The Unbelievable
Gwenpool_ by the same creative team was announced, starting in April 2016.[37]

### "House of M"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: "House of M"")]

In the reality seen in the "[House of M](/wiki/House_of_M "House of M")"
storyline, in which the [Scarlet Witch](/wiki/Scarlet_Witch "Scarlet Witch")
alters reality to make mutants the ruling class over humans, Gwen was never
killed. Instead, she married Peter Parker, and the couple had a young son. She
had become a scientist, a savvy businesswoman, and a peace activist – and had
a decidedly hostile relationship with [chemical weapon](/wiki/Chemical_warfare
"Chemical warfare") developer [Norman Osborn](/wiki/Green_Goblin "Green
Goblin"). Mary Jane Watson, a popular actress in this reality, played Gwen
Stacy in the film adaptation of Spider-Man's life story. Gwen and her father
read textual accounts of their deaths in the main universe, though they
believe this simply to be the morbid imaginings of Peter Parker, who is
suffering from mental health issues.[38]

### _Marvel
Adventures_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Marvel Adventures")]

Gwen Stacy first appeared in _[Marvel Adventures Spider-
Man](/wiki/Marvel_Adventures_Spider-Man "Marvel Adventures Spider-Man")_ #53
as a new student of Midtown High. She had transferred from her previous school
after the Torino Gang, a powerful New York mob, began harassing her in an
attempt to keep her father, police captain George Stacy, from arresting
members of their gang. However, the Torinos continued to harass Gwen at
Midtown, prompting Spider-Man to help the police take down the gang.[39] Like
her father, Gwen believes Spider-Man is a hero. She subsequently began
participating in a "Spider-Man Appreciation Society" designed to foster better
public opinion of Spider-Man.[40] Gwen is also attracted to Spider-Man's alter
ego Peter Parker; although she openly flirted with him, Peter began dating a
different girl, [Sophia "Chat" Sanduval](/wiki/Sophia_%22Chat%22_Sanduval
"Sophia "Chat" Sanduval"), which made Gwen very unhappy.[41] Later, Gwen was
brainwashed by [Emma Frost](/wiki/Emma_Frost "Emma Frost") into believing
_she_ was dating Peter. Gwen's brainwashing wore off (or was undone by Emma),
but Gwen now believes her relationship with Peter ended when he chose Chat
over her,[42] causing her to treat Chat very coldly. She has since warmed to
Chat, however.[43] Recently, Gwen began a close friendship with Carter Torino
who is the grandson of the head of the Torino Gang.[40] Their relationship is
complicated by the fact Gwen's father is still trying to take down Carter's
criminal family.[44]

### _Marvel Zombies
Return_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Marvel Zombies Return")]

In the limited series, _[Marvel Zombies Return](/wiki/Marvel_Zombies_Return
"Marvel Zombies Return")_ , Gwen of 'Earth Z' is still a college student out
with her friends Mary Jane and Harry Osborn. The zombified Spider-Man travels
to this earth and, despite his best intentions, turns the [Sinister
Six](/wiki/Sinister_Six "Sinister Six"). They then slay and partly consume
Gwen and her friends. To stop the spread of the virus, Spider-Man obliterates
the bodies.[45]

### _Powerless_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Powerless")]

In the _Powerless_ mini-series, Gwen Stacy again appears as the girlfriend of
Peter Parker. Norman Osborn again kidnaps and attempts to kill her as a part
of a plan to intimidate Peter. In a twist, the powerless Peter (with a limb
crippled from a spider bite) manages to save Gwen from falling to her
death.[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### _Spider-Gwen_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Spider-Gwen")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/52/Spider-Gwen.png/170px-
Spider-Gwen.png)](/wiki/File:Spider-Gwen.png)

[](/wiki/File:Spider-Gwen.png "Enlarge")

Gwen Stacy as Spider-Woman (nicknamed "The White Widow" by
[cosplayers](/wiki/Cosplayers "Cosplayers")) in an alternate universe. Named
"Spider-Gwen" by the fans and authors.

Main article: [Spider-Woman (Gwen Stacy)](/wiki/Spider-Woman_\(Gwen_Stacy\)
"Spider-Woman \(Gwen Stacy\)")

In the alternate reality designated Earth-65, Gwen Stacy is the one bitten by
the radioactive spider, and becomes a superhero going by the name of [Spider-
Woman](/wiki/Spider-Woman#Other_versions "Spider-Woman"). She is also a member
of a band fronted by Mary Jane Watson, simply called the Mary Janes. Shortly
after Gwen begins fighting crime, Peter Parker attempts to exact revenge on
those who bullied him, becoming this universe's version of the
[Lizard](/wiki/Lizard_\(comics\) "Lizard \(comics\)"). Gwen subdues him, but
Peter dies towards the end of the battle due to the chemical he used. Spider-
Woman is blamed for his death, causing an outcry for her arrest, led by [J.
Jonah Jameson](/wiki/J._Jonah_Jameson "J. Jonah Jameson"). Her father, who is
also a police chief in this world, begins a hunt for her. This follows Gwen
into college, where she is still a member of the Mary Janes. At a gig of
theirs, an assassin is sent after Gwen's father, who is in the audience. Gwen
defeats the assassin, the audience and band clearing out during the battle.
While they are alone, Captain Stacy holds Spider-Woman at gun point, with Gwen
taking off her mask to reveal who she is. Shocked upon learning Spider-Woman's
identity, he tells her to run before he changes his mind. In the distance, the
Captain Britain from Earth-833, called Spider-UK, is watching, saying that
Gwen will "do quite nicely."[46]

Gwen is recruited by Spider-UK to team up with other Spider-Totems across the
multiverse, and next appears on Earth-616 with Old Man Spider-Man of Earth-4
and [Spider-Man of Earth-70105](/wiki/Bullet_Points_\(comics\) "Bullet Points
\(comics\)") (who in that reality is [Bruce Banner](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\)
"Hulk \(comics\)")) to rescue [Kaine](/wiki/Kaine_Parker "Kaine Parker"), who
was under attack by the Inheritors.[47] Marvel-616 Peter is hesitant to put
Gwen in action and she is told by the others of how he failed to save her in
his world. However he does recruit her for a mission and they both agree to
look out for each other.[48] Gwen is sent to recruit an alternate version of
Peter Parker who is driven insane after he failed to save the Gwen Stacy in
his dimension, killed the Green Goblin, and became the
[Hobgoblin](/wiki/Hobgoblin_\(comics\) "Hobgoblin \(comics\)"). She tells him
that he can become the man he once was if he joins them, but they are attacked
by the Inheritors. Hobgoblin sacrifices himself to save Gwen.[49]

After the events of _Spider-Verse_ , Gwen returns to her home of Earth-65
where she continues her career as Spider-Woman in her own solo series,
_Spider-Gwen_. She first saves George Stacy from mercenary [Aleksei
Sytsevich](/wiki/Rhino_\(comics\) "Rhino \(comics\)") who was sent by [Wilson
Fisk](/wiki/Kingpin_\(comics\) "Kingpin \(comics\)") and his lawyer [Matt
Murdock](/wiki/Daredevil_\(Marvel_Comics_character\) "Daredevil \(Marvel
Comics character\)") to target him.[50] Then she begins a hunt for the
[Vulture](/wiki/Vulture_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Vulture \(Marvel Comics\)") who has
been terrorizing the city in her absence.[51]

She appears as one of the main characters in the _[Secret
Wars](/wiki/Secret_Wars_\(2015_comic_book\) "Secret Wars \(2015 comic
book\)")_ _Spider-Verse_ event with [Spider-Ham](/wiki/Spider-Ham "Spider-
Ham"), [Spider-Girl](/wiki/Anya_Corazon "Anya Corazon"), [Spider-
UK](/wiki/Spider-UK "Spider-UK"), [Spider-Man Noir](/wiki/Spider-Man_Noir
"Spider-Man Noir"), and [Spider-Man India](/wiki/Spider-Man_India "Spider-Man
India") in a Battleworld called Archania ruled by Norman Osborn. They
eventually form a team called the Web Warriors where they help other Spider-
Men and Women in various dimensions. A child version of her also appears in
_Giant Size Little Marvel Avengers vs X-Men_ as a new kid that Tony Stark
tries to ask out on a date. She rejects him because he's a kid with a goatee
and mustache. Another version of her is a member of Arcadia's's
[A-Force](/wiki/A-Force "A-Force"). On Earth-8, she is married to Miles
Morales and they have two children with Spider Powers.[52]

### _Spider-Punk_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Spider-Punk")]

In an issue of Web Warriors, [Spider-Punk](/wiki/Prowler_\(comics\) "Prowler
\(comics\)") mentions that the Gwen Stacy in his dimension was a musical
icon.[53]

### _Spider-Man: Fairy
Tales_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Spider-Man: Fairy Tales")]

Issue #1 of _[Spider-Man: Fairy Tales](/wiki/Spider-Man:_Fairy_Tales "Spider-
Man: Fairy Tales")_ follows the fairy tale of [Little Red Riding
Hood](/wiki/Little_Red_Riding_Hood "Little Red Riding Hood"), reimagined with
Mary Jane Watson as the titular character. Gwen Stacy has been previously
killed by the wolf. Issue #4 is an adaption of [Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella
"Cinderella") with Gwen as Princess Gwendolyn. She falls in love with the
masked "Prince of Arachne," who is revealed to be Peter Parker, servant to
[Sir Osborn](/wiki/Green_Goblin "Green Goblin"), but is killed during a fight
between Osborn and Parker.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### _Spider-Man Loves Mary
Jane_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Spider-Man Loves Mary Jane")]

Gwen Stacy first appears at the end of _[Spider-Man Loves Mary
Jane](/wiki/Spider-Man_Loves_Mary_Jane "Spider-Man Loves Mary Jane")_ #5. She
is the new girl at school and quickly becomes close friends with Peter Parker.
In _[Spider-Man Loves Mary Jane](/wiki/Spider-Man_Loves_Mary_Jane "Spider-Man
Loves Mary Jane")_ #9, Peter and Gwen take their relationship to the next
level by sharing a tender kiss, much to the dismay of [Mary
Jane](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson"). They date for a time, though
Gwen breaks up with Peter when she learns Mary Jane is the girl he truly
loves. MJ, attempting to fix this, breaks up with Peter and reunites with
Harry. Peter cannot commit to Gwen. She is unwilling to accept him as a friend
and not a boyfriend.[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### _Spider-Man
Unlimited_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Spider-Man Unlimited")]

In the fourth issue of the comic book based on the _[Spider-Man
Unlimited](/wiki/Spider-Man_Unlimited "Spider-Man Unlimited")_ animated
series, Spidey encounters a [Counter-Earth](/wiki/Counter-Earth_\(comics\)
"Counter-Earth \(comics\)") version of Gwen Stacy. She helps him escape a
hidden paradise known as "The Haven".[54]

### Ultimate
Marvel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Ultimate Marvel")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a9/Gwen_Stacy_%28Earth-1610%29.png/170px-
Gwen_Stacy_%28Earth-1610%29.png)](/wiki/File:Gwen_Stacy_\(Earth-1610\).png)

[](/wiki/File:Gwen_Stacy_\(Earth-1610\).png "Enlarge")

Gwen Stacy in _Ultimate Spider-Man_.

In the [Ultimate Marvel](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate Marvel")
[continuity](/wiki/Continuity_\(fiction\) "Continuity \(fiction\)"), Gwen
Stacy first appears in _[Ultimate Spider-Man](/wiki/Ultimate_Spider-Man
"Ultimate Spider-Man")_ #14 (December 2001) as a teenage girl at Peter's high
school. In this continuity, Gwen, whose rendition by artist [Mark
Bagley](/wiki/Mark_Bagley "Mark Bagley") was inspired by an early-career
[Madonna](/wiki/Madonna_\(entertainer\) "Madonna \(entertainer\)"),[55] has
amber eyes, wears punk-style clothing, and harbors a rebellious
personality.[56] In her first appearance she gives a rousing speech on 'super
powers'; in the next issue she pulls a knife on [Kong](/wiki/Kenny_McFarlane
"Kenny McFarlane"), a classmate who was bullying Peter. She is suspended from
school temporarily. Gwen becomes friends with Peter, which leads [Mary Jane
Watson](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson#Ultimate "Mary Jane Watson") to believe Gwen is
vying for his affections.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Gwen is later taken in by [Aunt May](/wiki/Aunt_May "Aunt May") after her
father, police captain John Stacy, is killed by a burglar wearing a Spider-Man
costume. Her estranged mother does not want to take her in. Her living in the
Parker house creates more tension between Peter and Mary Jane, and leads to
their temporary break-up. Peter's relationship with Gwen is further
complicated by her hatred of Spider-Man, whom she blames for her father's
death. When Peter finds his friend [Eddie Brock](/wiki/Eddie_Brock "Eddie
Brock"), Gwen confides in him about her feelings of isolation. Eddie then
tries to kiss her. Gwen is shocked.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] When she
eventually learns Peter is Spider-Man, the angry Gwen pulls her father's gun
on him. Fortunately, he manages to convince her he is not to blame for her
father's death. Gwen runs off but returns, explaining she is just really mad
at everything at the moment. She wouldn't have really shot him, a fact Peter
already knew because his spider sense didn't go off despite Gwen's wrath. Gwen
then agrees to keep his secret.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Gwen Stacy dies in _Ultimate Spider-Man_ #62. Before her death, she made peace
with Mary Jane and assured her she never had romantic feelings for Peter. She
considered him just as a friend. She is killed by
[Carnage](/wiki/Carnage_\(comics\) "Carnage \(comics\)"), a vampiric monster
made by the splicing of [genetic](/wiki/Genetics "Genetics") material from
Peter Parker, his father, and [Dr. Curt
Connors](/wiki/Lizard_\(comics\)#Ultimate_Lizard "Lizard \(comics\)").
Although Peter is not in the area when she dies, he still feels some
responsibility for her death, as he allowed Dr. Connors to use his genetic
material for experimentation. His guilt makes him decide to retire as Spider-
Man for a while. Eventually, he takes up his hero identity when his
responsibility for the innocent becomes too great to overlook.[_[volume &
issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] At
the end of the arc, there was an issue that dealt with Gwen's death. [Flash
Thompson](/wiki/Flash_Thompson "Flash Thompson") makes an off-color remark
about Gwen's passing. It infuriates MJ to the point where she physically
attacks Flash. It is revealed Flash had a crush on Gwen all along.[_[volume &
issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

A girl seeming to be Gwen Stacy appears in _Ultimate Spider-Man #98_. Says
_Ultimate artist_ [Mark Bagley](/wiki/Mark_Bagley "Mark Bagley"), "Gwen’s
return is integral to the Clone storyline and is basically a way to rock
Peter's world...again."[_[dead link](/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot "Wikipedia:Link
rot")_][57] In this issue "Gwen" appears to have no memory of her "death" and
believes she was in a hospital, from which she has escaped. In issue #100,
after a raft of revelations, the stress of the situation enrages "Gwen". She
transforms into what appears to be [Carnage](/wiki/Carnage_\(comics\) "Carnage
\(comics\)") before leaping out the window.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] In the
next issue, "[Richard Parker](/wiki/Richard_and_Mary_Parker "Richard and Mary
Parker")" claims "Gwen" should not have met Peter at all, and was merely an
experiment in [stem cell research](/wiki/Stem_cell_research "Stem cell
research"). This Gwen/Carnage fights with the Fantastic Four, Nick Fury, and
the Spider-Slayer drones, until she is knocked unconscious by a beam of light,
and taken into custody. In issue #113, Norman Osborn as the Green Goblin
causes a massive prison break from the Triskelion. An inmate appearing to be
'Gwen' walks out amidst the chaos, disappearing in the shadows. It has been
revealed the creature posing as Gwen Stacy is still the original Ultimate
Carnage Spider-Man faced earlier in its run. After "devouring" Gwen, this
incarnation of Carnage has gone on to mimic her "essence" and now believes
itself to be Gwen Stacy.[_[dead link](/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot "Wikipedia:Link
rot")_][58]

During the "War of the Symbiotes" storyline, Gwen/Carnage's back story in the
Triskelion is revealed. It is shown Gwen has been taking some form of therapy
with Tony Stark. However, when the Green Goblin broke out of the Triskelion,
Gwen escaped and went to Peter Parker's house in a confused and terrified
state, with Carnage's face on her body. During an exchange between Peter and
Gwen, Eddie Brock attempts to attack Aunt May and retake his symbiote. In a
rage, Spider-Man engages Venom on a nearby rooftop. During the fight, Gwen is
shown to be able to use her symbiote to fight off Eddie but Eddie reabsorbs
his symbiote along with the Carnage symbiote rendering Gwen Stacy an average
girl. After SHIELD intervenes, SHIELD Director Danvers states Gwen will remain
in S.H.I.E.L.D. custody. Peter and May argue for her to come back to live with
them, with Tony Stark supporting the Parkers. In _Ultimate Spider-Man_ #129,
the Parkers are now helping to rebuild Gwen's life. Her ghastly experience
with the Carnage symbiote also causes her to develop a [death
anxiety](/wiki/Death_anxiety_\(psychology\) "Death anxiety \(psychology\)")
she gradually controls. Six months after the "Ultimatum" storyline, in
_Ultimate Comics Spider-Man_ #1, Gwen is living with the Parkers again and
seems to be dating Peter. However, circumstances involving the Chameleon made
Gwen realize she made a mistake dating Peter. She breaks up with him, but
still lives with the Parkers due to Gwen and Aunt May has become close in a
surrogate mother-daughter fashion.

After Peter's death, Gwen and May re-located in [France](/wiki/France
"France"), but returned to New York after hearing about the re-emergence of a
[new Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(Miles_Morales\) "Spider-Man \(Miles
Morales\)").[59][60] Afterwards, they meet the Peter Parker of the
[Earth-616](/wiki/Earth-616 "Earth-616") continuity after he was accidentally
and briefly sent to the Ultimate universe,[61] with Gwen being intrigued to
learn about her counterpart (although she is not informed that her other self
dead, Gwen also "neglecting" to tell Peter that she had died and revived), as
she also attempts to tell Mary Jane about the other Peter's arrival in their
world.[62] When Green Goblin escapes custody after S.H.I.E.L.D. was shut down,
he arrives at the front yard of Aunt May's house and confronts the new Spider-
Man.[63] Gwen and Aunt May are inside watching the television where the battle
of the new Spider-Man and Green Goblin was being broadcast. Soon, Spider-Man
emerges to aid the new Spider-Man in the fight, to the surprise of Gwen and
Aunt May. Green Goblin flees at his arrival and the two Spider-Men depart.
Gwen is unsure of the identity of the original Spider-Man, however, Aunt May
assures her that his motives show that it him.[64] Later, Gwen and Aunt May
walk over to Mary Jane's house and overhear Peter's unknown resurrection. Gwen
sprints over and joyfully reunites with him.[65] After the two Spider-Men
defeat Green Goblin, Peter tells Gwen that he intends to go on a quest to find
out the truth of his mystery resurrection.[66]

Early in the series, _Ultimate Spider-Man #25_ (October 2002) paid homage to
Gwen Stacy's death in the [Earth-616](/wiki/Earth-616 "Earth-616") continuity,
although Gwen herself was not involved. The Green Goblin tossed Mary Jane off
the [Queensboro Bridge](/wiki/Queensboro_Bridge "Queensboro Bridge"). Spider-
Man caught her leg with his webbing, just as with Gwen. The issue ended with a
cliffhanger: when Spider-Man pulled Mary Jane up, she appeared to be either
unconscious or dead. The cliffhanger was resolved in the next issue when Mary
Jane awoke in #26, uninjured.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### _What If_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: What If")]

  * In "What if Gwen Stacy had lived?", Peter saves Gwen by jumping after her rather than catching her with a web-line. In doing this, he cushions her from the impact as they hit the water and subsequently gives her CPR. After regaining consciousness, Gwen sees him without his mask. After explaining himself to her, Peter proposes to Gwen, and she accepts. Meanwhile, the Green Goblin mails to [J. Jonah Jameson](/wiki/J._Jonah_Jameson "J. Jonah Jameson") proof of Spider-Man's real identity. On the day of Peter's wedding to Gwen, Jonah has published the expose and uses it to acquire a warrant for Peter's arrest. Peter escapes from the police moments after his wedding to Gwen, but the issue ends with Peter on the run from the law and pondering his uncertain future. As the issue ends, Gwen departs with [Joe 'Robbie' Robertson](/wiki/Robbie_Robertson_\(comics\) "Robbie Robertson \(comics\)"), who promises Gwen they will do whatever they can to help Peter and quits the _Bugle_.[67]
  * In "What If Spider-Man Had Kept His Six Arms?", Spider-Man (whose six-arms mutation was permanent here) is able to prevent Gwen Stacy's death.[68]
  * At the very end of [Peter David](/wiki/Peter_David "Peter David")'s one-shot "What If: The Other," Peter Parker (now calling himself "Poison") uses part of the [Venom](/wiki/Venom_\(Marvel_Comics_character\) "Venom \(Marvel Comics character\)") symbiote attached to him in the resurrection of Gwen Stacy. She takes the appearance of [Carnage](/wiki/Carnage_\(comics\) "Carnage \(comics\)").[69]

### Television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Television")]

  * Gwen Stacy was deliberately excluded from the 1990s _[Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(1994_TV_series\) "Spider-Man \(1994 TV series\)")_ animated series as the creators felt they could neither allow her to live nor deliberately include a character who was going to die.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] An alternate version of the character did appear in the series finale, voiced by [Mary Kay Bergman](/wiki/Mary_Kay_Bergman "Mary Kay Bergman"). The fiancée of Spider-Man's high-tech armored counterpart in this parallel universe, the primary version of [Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man") meets Gwen for the first time. Gwen plays a role in help defeating [Spider-Carnage](/wiki/Ben_Reilly "Ben Reilly").
  * Gwen Stacy appears as a central character in _[The Spectacular Spider-Man](/wiki/The_Spectacular_Spider-Man_\(TV_series\) "The Spectacular Spider-Man \(TV series\)")_ , voiced by [Lacey Chabert](/wiki/Lacey_Chabert "Lacey Chabert"). Depicted as a teenager, this version is friends with Peter Parker and [Harry Osborn](/wiki/Harry_Osborn "Harry Osborn") and is the daughter of [George Stacy](/wiki/George_Stacy "George Stacy"). She has hidden romantic feelings for Peter, being hurt several times when he expressed interest in other girls. Throughout season one, she becomes concerned when Harry become addicted to Gobulin Green. At the end of season one, she kisses Peter, leaving them in an awkward standing in season two. Despite their feeling for each other, Peter begins dating [Liz Allan](/wiki/Liz_Allan "Liz Allan") and she dates Harry. In the series finale, "Final Curtain", she and Peter acknowledge how they feel about each other, and agree to break up with Harry and Liz. However, after [Norman Osborn](/wiki/Norman_Osborn "Norman Osborn")'s apparent death, Gwen stays in a relationship with Harry because she would be the only one to care for him.
  * A variation of Spider-Gwen, native to [Miles Morales](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(Miles_Morales\) "Spider-Man \(Miles Morales\)")' dimension shows up in the final part of Return to the Spider-verse in _[Ultimate Spider-Man vs. the Sinister Six](/wiki/Ultimate_Spider-Man_\(TV_series\) "Ultimate Spider-Man \(TV series\)")_ , voiced by [Dove Cameron](/wiki/Dove_Cameron "Dove Cameron"). This version doesn't have Spider powers and instead relies on tech stolen from her father's robot program to become Spider-Woman, with the help of her world's Aunt May after Miles was transported to the alternate dimension early in the season. She is a big help in the final battle against Peter Parker's villainous counterpart Wolf-Spider. Gwen also stated she was a friend of her dimension's Peter Parker before his death.
  * Gwen Stacy as Spider-Gwen appears in the 2017 series _[Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(2017_TV_series\) "Spider-Man \(2017 TV series\)")_ ,[70] voiced by [Laura Bailey](/wiki/Laura_Bailey_\(voice_actress\) "Laura Bailey \(voice actress\)").[71] This version is one of Peter's classmates at Horizon High and specializes in DNA formulas. She was inspired to pursue science by her uncle, Raymond Warren, later revealed to be the villainous Jackal. In the "Spider Island" event, she becomes Spider-Gwen after being exposed to the Jackal's chemicals and assists Spider-Man as a hero, but is later mutated into a giant spider as the experiment starts affecting the rest of New York (similar to [Carlie Cooper](/wiki/Carlie_Cooper "Carlie Cooper")'s role in the original story). She is later cured in the climax of the story.

### Film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Film")]

#### Sam Raimi
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Sam Raimi series")]

  * A student in Peter Parker's university class in _[Spider-Man 2](/wiki/Spider-Man_2 "Spider-Man 2")_ , portrayed by [Ellen Pompeo](/wiki/Ellen_Pompeo "Ellen Pompeo"), is identified as Gwen Stacy in the film's novelization.
  * Gwen Stacy is portrayed by [Bryce Dallas Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas Howard") in _[Spider-Man 3](/wiki/Spider-Man_3 "Spider-Man 3")_. She is a potential new [love interest](/wiki/Romantic_interest "Romantic interest") for [Peter Parker](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man"), serving as an unintended rival to [Mary Jane Watson](/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson"). Gwen is a classmate and lab partner of Peter Parker and Spider-Man rescues her early in the film from a construction crane accident. She kisses an upside-down Spider-Man in similar fashion to how Mary Jane did in _[Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man_\(2002_film\) "Spider-Man \(2002 film\)")_ which causes Mary Jane to become angry and hurt. As Peter is at the top of [Dr. Connors](/wiki/Lizard_\(comics\) "Lizard \(comics\)")'s [quantum mechanics](/wiki/Quantum_mechanics "Quantum mechanics") class, he tutors her. She considers Peter a [genius](/wiki/Genius "Genius") and is very fond of him. She is also friends with [Eddie Brock](/wiki/Eddie_Brock "Eddie Brock") as he took pictures of her so Gwen could be a model. Brock's relationship is short-lived, as Peter, under the influence of the symbiote, steals her from Eddie. He dances with her at the same jazz club where Mary Jane works, but Gwen realizes Peter is doing this to make Mary Jane jealous. Gwen, upset about this, approaches Mary Jane, apologizes, and storms out of the club, leaving Peter behind. She is later present at [Harry Osborn](/wiki/Harry_Osborn "Harry Osborn")'s funeral.
  * [Bryce Dallas Howard](/wiki/Bryce_Dallas_Howard "Bryce Dallas Howard") said she would love to be a part of any continuation of the film franchise, while acknowledging her character's opportunity may have passed, especially after _Spider-Man 3_ ended with Peter and Mary Jane once again in each other’s arms. In May 2007, actor [James Cromwell](/wiki/James_Cromwell "James Cromwell"), who played Captain Stacy in the film stated he thought the natural progression for the character would be for both to die early in _[Spider-Man 4](/wiki/Spider-Man_4 "Spider-Man 4")_ , mirroring the comics. Howard said a death would not have bothered her. The film was ultimately unmade, although Stacy was in the draft.

#### Marc Webb
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Marc Webb series")]

  * [Emma Stone](/wiki/Emma_Stone "Emma Stone") portrays Gwen Stacy in _[The Amazing Spider-Man](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_\(2012_film\) "The Amazing Spider-Man \(2012 film\)")_ as Peter Parker's love interest. She works as an assistant at Dr. Curt Connors's laboratory at [Oscorp](/wiki/Oscorp "Oscorp"), where Peter is bitten by a genetically-engineered spider. She subsequently develops a crush on him, and he soon reveals his secret identity as Spider-Man to her. Gwen plays an important role in the [Lizard](/wiki/Lizard_\(comics\) "Lizard \(comics\)")'s defeat, by helping Peter develop an antidote for the serum that mutates people into reptilian hybrids through cross-species genetics, using her own scientific background. Unfortunately, her father is killed by the Lizard before Peter can defeat the villain. George begs Peter to keep Gwen out of his dangerous life. Peter honors that vow without telling Gwen immediately; this affronts Gwen until she realizes what her father did, and subsequently forgives Peter. However, when Peter later wonders if he should keep that promise, she just smiles.
  * Emma Stone reprises her role as Gwen Stacy in _[The Amazing Spider-Man 2](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_2 "The Amazing Spider-Man 2")_. Gwen continues to work at Oscorp, which is owned by [Harry Osborn](/wiki/Harry_Osborn "Harry Osborn"), Peter's best friend. By now, Peter and Gwen have decided to keep their relationship platonic, but Peter's romantic feelings for her are rekindled when she tells him that she is going to [England](/wiki/England "England") to study medicine at [Somerville College](/wiki/Somerville_College,_Oxford "Somerville College, Oxford"), [Oxford University](/wiki/Oxford_University "Oxford University"). When Oscorp employee Max Dillon suffers an industrial accident and becomes the villain [Electro](/wiki/Electro_\(comics\) "Electro \(comics\)"), Gwen starts asking questions; Donald Menken, a high ranking and mutinous Oscorp board member, decides that she is a threat, fires her and targets her for elimination. When Electro attacks the city's electricity supply, Gwen and Spider-Man work together to stop him. Just then, the Green Goblin kidnaps Gwen and holds her hostage atop of the power plant's clock tower, intent on drawing Spider-Man out. The Green Goblin throws Gwen through the tower's glass rooftop, but Spider-Man saves her by shooting a web for her to grab onto. The web eventually breaks, however, and Gwen falls to the ground far below. Spider-Man catches her with another web an instant too late, as her head hits the concrete floor, killing her instantly. Gwen's death sends Peter into a deep depression, and he decides to give up being Spider-Man. Five months later, he watches a video of Gwen's graduation speech, in which she tells her class that hope is what makes life worth living, even in the darkest of times. Inspired, Peter decides to once again become Spider-Man. As [viral marketing](/wiki/Viral_marketing "Viral marketing") for the film, a [Tumblr](/wiki/Tumblr "Tumblr") page was created for the character.[72]
  * In both films, [Kari Coleman](/wiki/Kari_Coleman "Kari Coleman"), Charlie DePew, [Skyler Gisondo](/wiki/Skyler_Gisondo "Skyler Gisondo") and Jacob Rodier portray the Stacy family: Helen Stacy (Gwen's mom), Philip Stacy, Howard Stacy, and Simon Stacy (Gwen's younger brothers) respectively.

#### Animation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Animation")]

  * Gwen Stacy will appear in _[Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse](/wiki/Spider-Man:_Into_the_Spider-Verse "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse")_ , voiced by [Hailee Steinfeld](/wiki/Hailee_Steinfeld "Hailee Steinfeld").[73]

### Video games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Stacy&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Video games")]

  * Gwen Stacy is briefly mentioned in _[Spider-Man: Edge of Time](/wiki/Spider-Man:_Edge_of_Time "Spider-Man: Edge of Time")_. When a futuristic version of Peter Parker reveals his plans to [Spider-Man 2099](/wiki/Spider-Man_2099 "Spider-Man 2099"), he mentions he can save the lives of [Uncle Ben](/wiki/Uncle_Ben "Uncle Ben"), Gwen Stacy, [George Stacy](/wiki/George_Stacy "George Stacy") and countless others.
  * Gwen Stacy appears in _[The Amazing Spider-Man](/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_\(2012_video_game\) "The Amazing Spider-Man \(2012 video game\)")_ voiced by [Kari Wahlgren](/wiki/Kari_Wahlgren "Kari Wahlgren").
  * Gwen Stacy makes her debut as a playable character in the [Lego](/wiki/Lego "Lego") game _[Lego Marvel Super Heroes](/wiki/Lego_Marvel_Super_Heroes "Lego Marvel Super Heroes")_ , voiced again by [Kari Wahlgren](/wiki/Kari_Wahlgren "Kari Wahlgren").
  * Gwen Stacy/Spider-Gwen is a playable character in Kabam's Android/iOS mobile game, _[Marvel: Contest of Champions](/wiki/Marvel:_Contest_of_Champions "Marvel: Contest of Champions")_.
  * Gwen Stacy is playable once again in _[Lego Marvel Super Heroes 2](/wiki/Lego_Marvel_Super_Heroes_2 "Lego Marvel Super Heroes 2")_ , but this time she can switch to her Spider-Gwen persona.
